questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is incorrect about the requirements of good lighting?

options.a: Colour of light should approximate daylight
options.c: Ceilings and roofs must have a 50% reflection factor

questions.explanation:
For good lighting in a room, ceilings and roofs must have an 80% reflection factor. The requirements of good lighting are: • Sufficient light to prevent eye strain. An illumination of 15 to 20-foot candles is accepted for 
satisfactory vision. • Distribution of light must be uniform with the same intensity over the whole field of work • Absence of glare • Absence of sharp shadows 600 
Sold by @itachibot • The source of light should be constant and steady • The colour of light should approximate the colour of daylight • Ceilings and roofs must have an 80% reflection factor. Walls must have 50 to 60%, furniture 30 
to 40% and floors 15 to 20%.

questions.question: Question 4: What is the basic minimum illumination for satisfactory vision?
questions.explanation:
The basic minimum illumination for satisfactory vision is accepted to be 15 - 20 foot candles. The 
illumination requirements vary from as little as 5 foot candles in stairways and corridors to 100 
foot candles in some industries.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is correct about daylight factor?

options.a: D.F. = Instantaneous illumination outdoors x 100/ Simultaneously occurring illumination
options.b: D.F. = Instantaneous illumination indoors x 100/ Simultaneously occurring illumination
options.c: D.F. = Delayed illumination indoors x 100/ Simultaneously occurring illumination outdoors
options.d: D.F. = Delayed illumination outdoors x 100/ Simultaneously occurring illumination indoors

questions.explanation:
Daylight factor (D.F.) is the ratio of the illumination at a given point to illumination at a point 
exposed simultaneously to the whole hemisphere of the sky (taken as 500-foot candles) excluding 
direct sunlight. The D.F. is used for the measurement of daylight. It is determined by a modified photo-electric 
meter called daylight factor meter. In living rooms, the daylight factor should be at least 8% and in kitchens, it should be 10%. 602 
Sold by @itachibot

Question 9: What is the upper limit of daily exposure to noise which people can tolerate without hearing 
damage?
questions.explanation:
The upper limit of daily exposure to noise which people can tolerate without hearing damage is 85 
dB. This is the maximum acceptable noise level. It has been observed that the human ear responds in a non-uniform way to different 
sound-pressure levels. A weighting curve, called curve A has been constructed which takes into 
account the subjective effects of sound. Sound-pressure levels are therefore expressed in dBA 
because this reflects the perception of that sound emission by the normal human ear. Acceptable noise levels in various surroundings are listed below. Locality

questions.question:
Question 11: A steel plant worker presented with sudden onset of bilateral hearing loss after hearing a 
blast in the plant. On examination, both his tympanic membranes were ruptured. What 
would have been the minimum intensity of the blast to cause this injury?
questions.explanation:
A minimum intensity of 160 dB can lead to rupture of the tympanic membrane, resulting in 
hearing loss.

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following is a unit of absorbed dose of radiation?
questions.explanation:
Rad is a unit of absorbed dose of radiation by tissue or material. It has been replaced by the SI 
unit which is gray (Gy).

questions.question: Question 16: What is the SI unit of radiation dose equivalent?
questions.explanation:
The SI unit of radiation dose equivalent is sievert (Sv). Dose equivalent (‘) = Absorbed dose (D) x Quality factor (Q) The quality factor depends upon the density of ionization produced in the tissue by radiation. The 
factor Q for X-rays, -rays and electrons is 1 and that for an alpha particle is 20.

questions.question: Question 17: What is the permissible dose of manmade radiation per year?
questions.explanation: The permissible dose of manmade radiation is 5 rads per year.

questions.question:
Question 18: A young girl who is 1 month pregnant is concerned about a chest X-ray that she had taken 3 
weeks back. What is the dose of radiation below which deterministic effects on the fetus are 
not seen?
questions.explanation:
606 
Sold by @itachibot Deterministic effects on the fetus are not seen below 5 rads or 50 mSv of radiation. Dose limits of radiation exposure are: • Occupational exposure - Effective dose should not exceed 20 mSv/year averaged over 5 
consecutive years / 30 mSv in a year. • General public exposure - Effective dose should not exceed 1 mSv/year • Occupational exposure for pregnant staff - Effective dose to the fetus should not exceed 
1mSv/year (same as the general public). For pregnant patients who require diagnostics with exposure to ionising radiation, the radiation 
protection principles are followed: • The exposure should be justified • The dose should be as low as reasonably achievable (ALARA principle) • The dose limit is not particularly specified as it involves a single time exposure to diagnostic 
radiation. Usually, the effective dose to the fetus is <1msv and deterministic effects to the fetus 
are not seen below 50 mSv (5 Rad).

questions.question: Question 19: What was the 10 days rule in radiation related to?
questions.explanation:
The 10 days rule in radiation was related to pregnancy. It is aimed at preventing unintentional 
exposure of the embryo or fetus to radiation. This rule states that if a radiograph is being done on the abdomen or pelvis of a woman in her 
childbearing age, then it should be done during the 10 days following the onset of menstruation. In most situations, there is growing evidence that strict adherence to the "ten-day rule" may be 
unnecessarily restrictive. Since organogenesis starts 3 to 5 weeks post-conception, it was felt that 
radiation exposure in early pregnancy couldn't result in malformation. Based on this, it was 
suggested to do away with the 10-day rule and replace it with a 28-day rule. This means that 
radiological examination if justified, can be carried throughout the cycle until a period is missed. 607 
Sold by @itachibot Waste and Sewage Disposal
